Here's one for you:

I'm helping some of our COBOL programmers learn Java i=
n their own time and once a week I do a small lunchtime "chalk and talk" se=
ssion. Lately, I have started introducing JUnit, on the grounds that the so=
oner I teach them good habits, the more likely they are to stick with them.=
 I'm using the java.lang.String class as the object being tested, so that w=
e only have to worry about writing one class instead of two.

My question i=
s: When testing overloaded methods (String.indexOf() in this specific case)=
, is it better for each overloaded method get it's own testXXX() method or =
is it ok to lump them all in the one test? I have them all in one test righ=
t now, on the grounds that the test is against the index feature, rather th=
an the individual methods.

Thoughts please.

Simon
